intro: Malvastrum coromandelianum, commonly known as the Indian mallow, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its showy, pink or purple flowers. The plant has palmately lobed leaves and produces capsules as its fruit, which contain numerous small seeds. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands or along water bodies. Due to its ornamental value, it is cultivated in gardens and used in traditional medicine in some regions.
